channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-11359] ASTTransformation cause "General error during instruction selection"
item.description:
When assembling the Grails project, I do obtain the following stacktrace:

 java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: size==0
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.asm.OperandStack.ensureStackNotEmpty(OperandStack.java:279)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.asm.OperandStack.replace(OperandStack.java:271)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitCastExpression(AsmClassGenerator.java:815)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.expr.CastExpression.visit(CastExpression.java:90)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.asm.StatementWriter.writeReturn(StatementWriter.java:615)
[. . .]

Tell me if you need a more complete stacktrace. I try to work around this bug, changing the AST, without success. The error looks the same each time.

To reproduce:
$ tar xvfz testcase-asttransform-ko.tar.gz

$ cd groovyInfra

$ ./gradlew publishMavenPublicationToMavenLocal

$ cd ..

$ cd t620g

$ ./gradlew assemble

=> BROKEN HERE

Thanks for your help !
item.environment:
$ java -fullversion
openjdk full version "17.0.10+7"
$ uname -a
Linux auoHome 6.6.26-1-MANJARO #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Wed Apr 10 20:11:08 UTC 2024 x86_64 GNU/Linux
item.summary: ASTTransformation cause "General error during instruction selection"

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
i just uploaded a new test-case version, fixing buildSrc.

Regards

I think something changed in the way generics are managed. I try many combinations.

ClassNode retClassNode0 = ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn)
ClassNode retClassNode1 = new GenericsType(ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn), [ClassHelper.make(methodNode.returnType.typeClass)] as ClassNode[], ClassHelper.make(Object)).type
ClassNode retClassNode2 = new GenericsType(ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn), ClassHelper.make(Object).makeArray() as ClassNode[], methodNode.returnType).type
ClassNode retClassNode3 = new GenericsType(ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn, false), [ClassHelper.make(methodNode.returnType.typeClass)] as ClassNode[], null).type
ClassNode retClassNode4 = new GenericsType(ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn)).lowerBound

ClassNode retClassNode = retClassNode3
ClassNode retClassNodeNoGenerics = ClassHelper.make(ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn, false).typeClass, false)

 
GetMethodReturn use generics:

@CompileStatic
final class GetMethodReturn<T> {
    final Method method
    final T value

    GetMethodReturn(final Method method, final T value) {
        this.method = method
        this.value = value
    }
}

 

And the method generator:

 ReturnStatement code = new ReturnStatement(
        new ConstructorCallExpression(
                retClassNodeNoGenerics,
                new ArgumentListExpression([
                        new StaticMethodCallExpression(
                                classNode,
                                "getMethod",
                                new ArgumentListExpression(
                                        [new ConstantExpression(methodNode.name)] as List<Expression>
                                )),
                        new MethodCallExpression(
                                new VariableExpression('this'),
                                methodNode.name,
                                [] as ArgumentListExpression),
                ] as List<Expression>)
        )
)

The objective is to generate something looking like this:

public GetMethodReturn<String> getDisplayName_() {
    return new GetMethodReturn(Item.class.getMethod("getDisplayName"), 
                               this.getDisplayName());
}

Ideas are welcomed.

Thanks for your support

FYI, After applying other modifications:

ClassNode retClassNode0 = ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn)
ClassNode retClassNode3 = new GenericsType(ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn, false), [ClassHelper.make(methodNode.returnType.typeClass)] as ClassNode[], null).type
ClassNode retClassNodeNoGenerics = ClassHelper.make(ClassHelper.make(GetMethodReturn, false).typeClass, false)

ReturnStatement code = new ReturnStatement(
    new CastExpression(retClassNode0,
                new ConstructorCallExpression(
                        retClassNodeNoGenerics,
                        new ArgumentListExpression([
                                new StaticMethodCallExpression(
                                        classNode,
                                        "getMethod",
                                        new ArgumentListExpression(
                                                [new ConstantExpression(methodNode.name)] as List<Expression>
                                        )),
                                new MethodCallExpression(
                                        new VariableExpression('this'),
                                        methodNode.name,
                                        [] as ArgumentListExpression),
                        ] as List<Expression>)
                )
        )
)

// cast something
new MethodNode(
        methodName,
        MethodNode.ACC_PUBLIC,
        retClassNode0,
        [] as Parameter[],
        [] as ClassNode[],
        code
)

I do obtain the following message:

A transform used a generics containing ClassNode ast.type.GetMethodReturn <T extends java.lang.Object> for the method public ast.type.GetMethodReturn getTruc_()  { ... } directly. You are not supposed to do this. Please create a new ClassNode referring to the old ClassNode and use the new ClassNode instead of the old one. Otherwise the compiler will create wrong descriptors and a potential NullPointerException in TypeResolver in the OpenJDK. If this is not your own doing, please report this bug to the writer of the transform.

I do not know if it is a progress.

If I am reading correctly, your transform is creating a method via the following sequence:

        String methodName = methodNode.name + '_'

        ClassNode retClassNode = GenericsUtils.makeClassSafeWithGenerics(GetMethodReturn, methodNode.returnType)

        ReturnStatement code = new ReturnStatement(
                    new CastExpression(retClassNode,
                                new ConstructorCallExpression(
                                        retClassNode,
                                        new ArgumentListExpression([
                                                new StaticMethodCallExpression(
                                                        classNode,
                                                        "getMethod",
                                                        new ArgumentListExpression(
                                                                [new ConstantExpression(methodNode.name)] as List<Expression>
                                                        )),
                                                new MethodCallExpression(
                                                        new VariableExpression('this'),
                                                        methodNode.name,
                                                        [] as ArgumentListExpression),
                                        ] as List<Expression>)
                                )
                        )
        )

// cast something
        new MethodNode(
                methodName,
                MethodNode.ACC_PUBLIC,
                GenericsUtils.makeClassSafeWithGenerics(GetMethodReturn, transformNativeTypeIntoClass(methodNode.returnType)),
                [] as Parameter[],
                [] as ClassNode[],
                code
        )

Classgen is processing the CastExpression when it finds that the operand stack is empty. The cast is the expression of the method's ReturnStatement. The operand stack underflow occurrs somewhere in you ConstructorCallExpression. One thing to try that is a common source of problems is capturing your MethodCallExpression and calling setImplicitThis(false) on it.

You can also set the return type of your method node to retClassNode instead of makeClassSafeWithGenerics(GetMethodReturn...

And I don't know if it helps to set the type of the StaticMethodCallExpression to String. You could step through the class generator and see what is on the operand stack as it works its way through the CCE.

Classgen is processing the CastExpression when it finds that the operand stack is empty. The cast is the expression of the method's ReturnStatement. The operand stack underflow occurrs somewhere in you ConstructorCallExpression. One thing to try that is a common source of problems is capturing your MethodCallExpression and calling setImplicitThis(false) on it.

Thanks for those advises, I can even get ride of the cast... I will give it a try.

You can also set the return type of your method node to retClassNode instead of makeClassSafeWithGenerics(GetMethodReturn...

I already do this, I might have done something wrong, but I get the same error.

And I don't know if it helps to set the type of the StaticMethodCallExpression to String. You could step through the class generator and see what is on the operand stack as it works its way through the CCE.

Sure it helps ! In fact it is the return type of the String getTtuc(); method, but I am thinking now : "Why a Static call on a non-static class member...".

I will try to step through the class generator, even if I am not sure how to do that ATM. Do I need to debug build ? or I am misunderstanding ?

Many thanks !
Your second build, you can set debug on the groovy compile. Then you attach with your ide. I can be more specific if you need.

Here is how I process. If your process is any better, I would be happy to know about it:

1/ Attach jdb to groovyc:

jdb -sourcepath /home/xXx/dev/groovy/groovy-3.0.21/src/ -attach 5005

2/ Trace all what's happening:

dbgtrace

3/ Launch with:

cont

Here I obtain lot of traces, but I can guess the Expressions, they appears in traces:

[JDI: Looking up Class, signature='Lorg/codehaus/groovy/ast/expr/{*}CastExpression{*};', id=2764]

I think I can improve this process with dbgtrace flags, but I do not find any docs, and jdb scripting.

If you have a better process, just let me know ! It is a long time since I used dbx, adb and others. I really liked those tools, and I do not really enjoy debugging via an IDE (I like IDE, but not to focus on debugging..). 

Thanks for your help!

jdb brings back some memories. If you can attach, then set a breakpoint in AsmClassGenerator visitStdMethod. When you get to the method that was created by the transform, you want to step through the visitReturnStatement and so on. Keep an eye on the OperandStack. After each method call and the constructor call there should be only the return types on the stack.

To keep you informed, here is what has been done regarding how the compiler generate the method:

  • I used expect, for the first time. This tool allows script automations. I attached the script, the syntax is not complex and things can get improved iteratively.
  • Then, I traced all methods via jdb AFTER reaching AsmClassGenerator.visitStdMethod (see expect file)

Then, I indented the output of the previous commands, with a Groovy script (attached).

The output file is huge, even for simple class code. So, I use grep / awk to format around expected symbols..

This process is arch and "brute force", but I am a little blind on what I am supposed to find. Nevertheless, it is fun in some ways.. Hope to find my error soon.

Regards

So what is happening is your class Tst is statically compiled, but your generated method getTruc_ is not properly setup for static compilation. So you can either write out the necessary metadata for that or you can tag your method with @groovy.transform.CompileDynamic, which depending on the compile stage that you generate the method, could be methodNode.putNodeMetaData(StaticCompilationMetadataKeys.STATIC_COMPILE_NODE, Boolean.FALSE);

Or you could remove static compilation from Tst

I would like to keep @CompileStatic.

It was working with Groovy 3.0.11, with little differences (there was no cast, see oldVersion).

What do you mean by "write out the necessary metadata" ? I am obliged to issue OpCode ?

EDIT: I found this Compile time metaprogramming will read it carefully.

EDIT2: The most relevant source of information comes from 
org.codehaus.groovy.transform package. I am looking at it.

Regards
For each method call and the constructor call, set DIRECT_METHOD_CALL_TARGET and INFERRED_TYPE.

Thanks for the tip, I can compile, I used org.codehaus.groovy.ast.tools.GeneralUtils it is far more readable now.
 
Thanks again !

Could compile without errors following Eric Milles advices.

        ConstructorCallExpression ctorGetMethodReturn = ctorX(
                GRM_TYPE,
                args(
                        callGetMethod,
                        callMethod
                )
        )

        ctorGetMethodReturn.putNodeMetaData(
                StaticTypesMarker.DIRECT_METHOD_CALL_TARGET, 
                GRM_TYPE.getDeclaredConstructors().first())
        ctorGetMethodReturn.putNodeMetaData(
                StaticTypesMarker.INFERRED_TYPE, 
                 GRM_TYPE)

Closing !
Thanks again !
